issues.description: The UML in the problem statement marks Farm.addAnimal(animal: Animal): void as private ( '-' ), but the intended design and the solution implement addAnimal as public and the provided Main example calls farm.addAnimal(...). If students read the UML literally they may conclude addAnimal should be private and be confused about how to add animals to the farm (or how the Main example should work).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the UML consistent with the intended API: change the visibility marker of addAnimal to public ('+' in the UML) and/or explicitly state in the text that addAnimal should be public so students can call farm.addAnimal(...). Ensure the template includes a public addAnimal(Animal) stub or documents that students must implement a public addAnimal method.

issues.description: The UML shows the Animal constructor as private ( '-' ) while the solution implements a public constructor (public Animal(String)). Since Animal is abstract and must be subclassed (subclasses need to call super(name)), a private constructor would prevent correct subclassing. This discrepancy between the UML and the working solution/template may confuse students about the required visibility of the Animal constructor.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the UML to show the Animal constructor with appropriate visibility (public or protected, use '+' or note 'protected') so it is clear that subclasses can invoke it. Alternatively add a note in the text explaining that the Animal constructor must be accessible to subclasses (e.g., public or protected).
